extends java.lang.Object

      • predict

        protected abstract double predict(int[] keys)
                           throws LibrecException
        predict a specific rating for user userIdx on item itemIdx with some other contexts indices, note that the prediction is not bounded. It is useful for building models with no need to bound predictions.
        Parameters:
        keys - user index, item index and context indices
        Returns:
        predictive rating for user userIdx on item itemIdx with some other contexts indices without bound
        Throws:
        LibrecException - if error occurs during predicting

      • predict

        protected double predict(int[] keys,
             boolean bound)
                  throws LibrecException
        predict a specific rating for user userIdx on item itemIdx with some other contexts indices. Tt is useful for evalution which requires predictions are bounded.
        Parameters:
        keys - user index, item index and context indices
        bound - whether there is a bound
        Returns:
        predictive rating for user userIdx on item itemIdx with some other contexts indices with bound
        Throws:
        LibrecException - if error occurs during predicting

      • isConverged

        protected boolean isConverged(int iter)
                       throws LibrecException
        Post each iteration, we do things:
        1. print debug information
        2. check if converged
        3. if not, adjust learning rate
        Parameters:
        iter - current iteration
        Returns:
        boolean: true if it is converged; false otherwise
        Throws:
        LibrecException - if error occurs

      • updateLRate

        protected void updateLRate(int iter)
        Update current learning rate after each epoch
        1. bold driver: Gemulla et al., Large-scale matrix factorization with distributed stochastic gradient descent, KDD 2011.
        2. constant decay: Niu et al, Hogwild!: A lock-free approach to parallelizing stochastic gradient descent, NIPS 2011.
        3. Leon Bottou, Stochastic Gradient Descent Tricks
        4. more ways to adapt learning rate can refer to: http://www.willamette.edu/~gorr/classes/cs449/momrate.html
        Parameters:
        iter - the current iteration
